title: GM debuts 2020 Corvette Stingray convertible: First-ever hardtop 'Vette
text:
CLOSE The radically new 2020 Chevrolet Corvette Stingray convertible was unveiled at the Kennedy Space Center in Florida on Wednesday, Oct. 2, 2019. It will start at $66,400 when sales begin early in 2020. Mark Phelan, Detroit Free Press Auto Critic

Who says convertibles are dead?

Not General Motors.

The automaker on late Wednesday revealed the first retractable hardtop in the history of its beloved Corvette sports car.

The 2020 Chevrolet Corvette Stingray convertible debuted, promising what should be the quietest and most comfortable interior since the first convertible ‘Vette debuted in 1953.

Prices for the radically new convertible will start at $66,400, a $7,500 bump from the base coupe, when sales begin early in 2020.

Chevy started from a clean sheet of paper developing the '20 'Vette, which is the eighth generation of the vehicle. Other innovations in both the Corvette coupe and convertible include moving the engine from the nose to just behind the passenger cabin to allow ever more powerful versions of America’s greatest sports car.

Roof opens at up to 30 mph

The two-piece power hardtop can be opened and closed at speeds up to 30 mph in just 16 seconds.

The top stows under a body-colored panel above the engine, between the passenger compartment and the rear wheels.

That’s called a mid-engined layout. Exotic sports cars like Ferraris, Lamborghinis and Porsches use it because putting the engine’s weight directly above the rear wheels allows the car to send more power to those wheels before they break loose and spin. The result: better acceleration and more usable power. The mid-engined platform also lends itself to good handling compared to often nose-heavy front-engine cars.

Six electric motors open and close the top, an arrangement Chevy says is more precise than the hydraulic and hand-operated mechanisms past 'Vettes used. Stowing the roof does not reduce space in the 'Vette’s rear trunk, which Chevy says can accommodate two golf bags. A second small trunk in the nose can hold an airline-spec carry-on and a laptop bag.

Peekaboo engine, twin nacelles

Unlike the Corvette coupe, which has a glass viewing plate over its engine, the convertible’s 6.2-liter, 8-cylinder engine is not visible. GM went to great lengths to make sure the engine still gets enough air to keep it cool when the roof is stowed on top of it.

The roof is body-colored plastic, but an optional metallic black finish called Carbon Flash is available for the roof and the two “nacelles” that slope down from behind the occupants’ heads to the rear deck.

The power rear window slides down into the Corvette’s body for open-air driving, but can be raised to reduce wind noise and buffeting. It can be opened when the top is on or off. The Corvette coupe’s rear window does not open.

Chevrolet introduced its Corvette Stingray convertible in Cape Canaveral, Florida on Wednesday, Oct. 2, 2019. (Photo: Mark Phelan, Detroit Free Press)

The nacelles are a design element borrowed from the classic CERV I and II (Corvette Engineering Research Vehicle) experimental cars and Corvette SS and SR2 race cars.

The drivetrain is unchanged from the coupe, 495 horsepower and 470 pound-feet of torque from the latest version of Chevy’s legendary small block V8 linked to an eight-speed dual-clutch automatic transmission from longtime 'Vette gearbox specialist Tremec. It’s the first dual clutch in Corvette history, and Chevy promises lightning fast shifts for better performance than a human-shifted manual could provide. Diehards will be able to override the electronic controls with paddle shifters, however.

Chevy says engineers tweaked the Corvette’s chassis and used new springs and dampers “to provide nearly the same performance as the coupe.” There’s no word yet on what the difference will be, but a rear spoiler borrowed from the Z51 performance package creates aerodynamic downforce to keep the car firmly planted on the road at high speeds.

GM builds the Corvette in Bowling Green, Kentucky. Production of right-hand-drive models for sale in countries such as Australia and Ireland is planned at a later date.

2020 Chevrolet Corvette Stingray convertible features twin nacelles behind the seats that recall the design of classic Corvette research vehicles and race cars of the 1950s and '60s. (Photo: Chevrolet)
